prompt: What is a balanced chemical equation?
target: A chemical equation in which the number of atoms of each element is the same on both the reactant and product sides, satisfying the law of conservation of mass.
A reaction in which two or more reactants combine to form a single product.
A reaction in which a single reactant breaks down to give two or more simpler products.
A decomposition reaction brought about by heating.
A decomposition reaction brought about by passing an electric current through a compound in its molten state or aqueous solution.
A decomposition reaction brought about by the action of light.
A reaction in which a more reactive element displaces a less reactive element from its compound.
A reaction in which there is an exchange of ions between two reacting compounds.
A double displacement reaction in which an insoluble solid (precipitate) is formed.
An insoluble solid substance that is formed from a solution during a chemical reaction.
A reaction between an acid and a base to form salt and water.
A process that involves the gain of oxygen, loss of hydrogen, or loss of electrons by a substance.
A process that involves the loss of oxygen, gain of hydrogen, or gain of electrons by a substance.
A chemical reaction in which both oxidation and reduction occur simultaneously.
A substance that causes oxidation of another substance and gets reduced itself.
A substance that causes reduction of another substance and gets oxidized itself.
The process of slow degradation or eating away of metals due to the action of air, moisture, or chemicals on their surface.
The corrosion of iron, forming a reddish-brown flaky substance called rust (hydrated iron(III) oxide).
The condition produced by aerial oxidation of fats and oils in foods marked by unpleasant smell and taste.
Substances that are added to foods containing fats and oils to prevent or slow down their oxidation and thus prevent rancidity.
A chemical reaction in which heat energy is released or evolved.
A chemical reaction in which heat energy is absorbed.

A substance that produces hydroxide ions (OH⁻) when dissolved in water, tastes bitter, feels soapy, and turns red litmus blue.
A base that is soluble in water.

A natural indicator obtained from lichens, which is red in acidic solution and blue in basic solution.
A synthetic indicator which is colorless in acidic and neutral solutions and pink in basic solutions.

Substances whose odor changes in acidic or basic media.

An acid that ionizes only partially in water to produce a low concentration of H⁺ ions.
A base that ionizes completely or almost completely in water to produce a high concentration of OH⁻ ions.
A base that ionizes only partially in water to produce a low concentration of OH⁻ ions.
A scale for measuring hydrogen ion concentration in a solution, ranging from 0 to 14, where pH 7 is neutral, pH < 7 is acidic, and pH > 7 is basic.
A mixture of several indicators that shows different colors at different pH values across the entire pH scale.
A mild base used to neutralize excess acid in the stomach and relieve indigestion.
An ionic compound formed from the reaction between an acid and a base (neutralization), consisting of a cation from the base and an anion from the acid.
An industrial process for the electrolysis of aqueous sodium chloride (brine) solution to produce sodium hydroxide, chlorine gas, and hydrogen gas.
A chemical compound (Calcium Oxychloride, CaOCl₂) used as a bleaching agent and disinfectant.
A mild base (Sodium Hydrogen Carbonate, NaHCO₃) used in baking, as an antacid, and in fire extinguishers.
A chemical compound (Sodium Carbonate Decahydrate, Na₂CO₃.10H₂O) used as a cleaning agent, in glass and soap industries, and for removing permanent hardness of water.
The fixed number of water molecules chemically attached to each formula unit of a salt in its crystalline form.
A salt that contains water of crystallization.
A salt that does not contain water of crystallization, or from which water of crystallization has been removed.
A white powder (Calcium Sulphate Hemihydrate, CaSO₄.½H₂O) that sets into a hard mass on mixing with water, used for making casts and molds.
A naturally occurring mineral (Calcium Sulphate Dihydrate, CaSO₄.2H₂O) used to make Plaster of Paris.
Elements that are typically shiny, malleable, ductile, good conductors of heat and electricity, and tend to lose electrons to form positive ions (cations).
Elements that are typically dull, brittle, poor conductors of heat and electricity (except graphite), and tend to gain electrons to form negative ions (anions) or share electrons.
The property of metals by which they can be beaten into thin sheets.
The property of metals by which they can be drawn into thin wires.

The property of metals to produce a ringing sound when struck.

Non-metal oxides that react with bases to form salt and water, and may dissolve in water to form acids.

prompt: What is the reactivity series of metals?
target: A list of metals arranged in decreasing order of their chemical reactivity.

Compounds formed by ionic bonds.
Naturally occurring chemical substances (elements or compounds) found in the Earth's crust.

Earthly impurities like sand, soil, and rock associated with an ore.
The science and technology of extracting metals from their ores and refining them for use.

The process of heating a carbonate ore strongly in the presence of limited or no air to convert it into its metal oxide.

A highly exothermic displacement reaction between a metal oxide (like iron(III) oxide) and a more reactive metal powder (like aluminium), used for welding.
The process of extracting highly reactive metals from their molten ores (chlorides or oxides) by passing an electric current.

A homogeneous mixture of two or more metals, or a metal and a non-metal, designed to have improved properties.
An alloy in which one of the metals is mercury.
The process of coating iron or steel with a thin layer of zinc to protect it from rusting.
An electrolytic process for producing a thick protective or decorative oxide layer on a metal, typically aluminium.
Compounds primarily made of carbon atoms, often bonded with hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur, and phosphorus.
A chemical bond formed by the mutual sharing of one or more pairs of electrons between two atoms.
The property of carbon to form four covalent bonds due to its four valence electrons.
The unique ability of carbon atoms to link with other carbon atoms through covalent bonds to form long straight chains, branched chains, or rings.
Different structural forms of the same element in the same physical state, which have different physical properties but similar chemical properties (e.g., diamond, graphite, fullerenes for carbon).
Organic compounds containing only carbon and hydrogen atoms.
Hydrocarbons in which all carbon-carbon bonds are single covalent bonds. (General formula: CₙH₂ₙ₊₂).
Hydrocarbons that contain one or more carbon-carbon double bonds (alkenes) or triple bonds (alkynes).
Unsaturated hydrocarbons containing at least one carbon-carbon double bond. (General formula: CₙH₂ₙ).
Unsaturated hydrocarbons containing at least one carbon-carbon triple bond. (General formula: CₙH₂ₙ₋₂).
Compounds that have the same molecular formula but different structural arrangements of atoms, and thus different properties.
An atom or a group of atoms present in an organic molecule that largely determines its characteristic chemical properties.

The conversion of an alcohol to a carboxylic acid (or aldehyde/ketone) by reaction with an oxidizing agent.

A reaction characteristic of saturated hydrocarbons where one or more hydrogen atoms are replaced by another atom or group of atoms (e.g., a halogen).
An alcohol (Ethyl Alcohol, C₂H₅OH) commonly used as a solvent, fuel, and in alcoholic beverages.
A carboxylic acid (Acetic Acid, CH₃COOH), the main component of vinegar.

Sodium or potassium salts of long-chain fatty acids (carboxylic acids), used as cleansing agents.
An aggregate of soap or detergent molecules in water, where the hydrophobic tails are in the interior and the hydrophilic heads are on the surface, capable of entrapping oil or grease.
Cleansing agents that are sodium salts of long-chain benzene sulphonic acids or long-chain alkyl hydrogen sulphates, which can lather even in hard water.
Water that contains dissolved salts of calcium and magnesium, which forms scum with soap.
